verses.text: Jesus called his twelve disciples to himself and gave them authority over unclean spirits, to drive them out, and to heal every disease and every sickness.
verses.comment: Jesus grants his disciples authority not only to proclaim but to act in his name, indicating a passing on of power and mission. This hints at a divinely established office for the apostles patterned after the Old Testament sending out of leaders (see Exodus 3:10).

verses.text: These are the names of the twelve apostles: first, Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother; James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother;
verses.comment: Peter is consistently listed first, showing a unique leadership role. The meaning of 'apostle' is 'one who is sent'.

verses.text: Philip and Bartholomew; Thomas and Matthew the tax collector; James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus;
verses.comment: Matthew mentions his former occupation (tax collector) to highlight the diversity and humility of the group Jesus chose.

verses.text: Simon the Zealot, and Judas Iscariot, the one who betrayed him.
verses.comment: The inclusion of Judas even among the twelve points to Jesus' foreknowledge and sovereign purpose in allowing betrayal to fulfill prophecy (cf. Psalm 41:9; John 13:18).

verses.text: These twelve Jesus sent out, commanding them, 'Do not go among the Gentiles or enter any town of the Samaritans.'
verses.comment: The initial mission is to Israel alone, while later (after the resurrection) Jesus commands outreach to all nations (Matt. 28:19). This demonstrates the priority of God’s covenant people.

verses.text: 'Go rather to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.'
verses.comment: Israel is depicted as lost sheep, echoing Old Testament language for God’s people in need of shepherds. See Ezekiel 34 for messianic shepherd imagery.

verses.text: 'And as you go, preach, saying, ‘The kingdom of heaven is at hand.’'
verses.comment: The core message is the arrival of the kingdom of heaven. Jesus’ ministry fulfills the messianic hope anticipated throughout the Old Testament.

verses.text: 'Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those with leprosy, cast out demons. Freely you have received, freely give.'
verses.comment: The apostles receive power for both physical and spiritual works, prefiguring ongoing ministry of healing and mercy through Christ’s people.

verses.text: 'Do not acquire gold, silver, or copper for your belts,'
verses.comment: Jesus calls for dependence and poverty among the apostles, trusting God’s provision. This model continues in later church history as a spiritual discipline.

verses.text: 'No bag for the journey, or two tunics, or sandals, or a staff; for the worker is worthy of his food.'
verses.comment: Ministry workers are to be provided for by those they serve. This principle of spiritual labor has deep roots, showing the dignity of those who labor in ministry.

verses.text: 'In whatever town or village you enter, search for someone worthy there, and stay at his home until you leave.'
verses.comment: Apostles are to seek hospitality among the worthy, highlighting both charity and discernment in receiving God’s messengers.

verses.text: 'As you enter the house, greet it.'
verses.comment: A gesture of peace and blessing from the apostles; similar ritual greetings are found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: 'If the household is worthy, let your peace come upon it; but if it is not worthy, let your peace return to you.'
verses.comment: A spiritual reality is present in the apostolic blessing; acceptance or rejection brings spiritual consequences.

verses.text: 'If anyone will not receive you or listen to your words, shake the dust from your feet when you leave that house or town.'
verses.comment: Shaking off the dust was a symbolic gesture showing separation from those who reject the message, signifying accountability for their choice.

verses.text: 'Truly I tell you, it will be more tolerable for the land of Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that town.'
verses.comment: Greater revelation incurs greater responsibility. Rejecting Christ and his apostles brings severe judgment.

verses.text: 'Behold, I am sending you out like sheep among wolves. So be as wise as serpents and innocent as doves.'
verses.comment: Jesus soberly prepares his apostles for persecution. Christians are to exercise prudence and innocence in hostile environments.

verses.text: 'Beware of people, for they will hand you over to councils and flog you in their synagogues.'
verses.comment: The apostles’ sufferings parallel the suffering of Christ and the prophets who came before. This foreshadows the experience of the early church.

verses.text: 'You will be brought before governors and kings for my sake, as a testimony to them and to the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: The suffering of apostles becomes a powerful witness to both Jews and Gentiles alike. See Paul’s later experiences in prison trials.

verses.text: 'But when they deliver you up, do not worry about how or what you should speak. For it will be given to you in that very hour what you are to say.'
verses.comment: Jesus promises the active help of the Holy Spirit, who works through the leaders of the church especially at crucial moments.

verses.text: 'For it is not you who speak, but the Spirit of your Father speaking through you.'
verses.comment: Apostolic teaching is divinely inspired, setting the precedent for guided doctrine and teaching through the ages.

verses.text: 'Brother will deliver up brother to death, and a father his child; and children will rise up against parents and cause them to be put to death.'
verses.comment: Quoting Micah 7:6, Jesus shows that persecution can divide even families. Faithful witness can bring conflict precisely because it confronts the world’s values.

verses.text: 'You will be hated by everyone because of my name. But the one who endures to the end will be saved.'
verses.comment: Perseverance in faith is necessary for salvation. Continuing to the end (final perseverance) is emphasized.

verses.text: 'When they persecute you in one town, flee to the next. For truly, I tell you, you will not finish going through the towns of Israel before the Son of Man comes.'
verses.comment: This points to the urgency and vastness of the mission, and perhaps to a near future coming in judgment (such as 70 AD) but also a future coming in glory.

verses.text: 'A disciple is not above the teacher, nor a servant above his master.'
verses.comment: Sharing in Jesus’ sufferings is part of following him. Servants must expect hardships if their master faced them.

verses.text: 'It is enough for the disciple to be like his teacher, and the servant like his master. If they have called the master of the house Beelzebul, how much more those of his household!'
verses.comment: Jesus prepares his followers for slander and rejection by the world, as he himself was called evil by his opponents.

verses.text: 'So do not fear them, for nothing is concealed that will not be revealed, or hidden that will not be known.'
verses.comment: At the final judgment, all truth and justice will prevail. God will vindicate his servants.

verses.text: 'What I tell you in the dark, speak in the light; and what you hear whispered in your ear, proclaim on the housetops.'
verses.comment: Apostolic preaching will bring to light the mysteries entrusted to them, leading ultimately to the full public revelation of Christ's teaching.

verses.text: 'Do not fear those who kill the body but cannot kill the soul. Rather, fear him who is able to destroy both soul and body in hell.'
verses.comment: True reverence belongs to God, whose judgment is sovereign over eternal destiny. This also alludes to the immortality of the soul.

verses.text: 'Are not two sparrows sold for a penny? Yet not one of them will fall to the ground apart from your Father.'
verses.comment: God’s providence extends even to the smallest creatures, emphasizing his intimate care for all creation—and especially his people.

verses.text: 'But even the hairs of your head are all numbered.'
verses.comment: Jesus stresses God’s detailed knowledge of each individual, which reassures the faithful in times of trial.

verses.text: 'So do not be afraid; you are more valuable than many sparrows.'
verses.comment: Every disciple is precious in God’s eyes—not one’s suffering or trial escapes his attention.

verses.text: 'Therefore, everyone who acknowledges me before others, I also will acknowledge before my Father who is in heaven.'
verses.comment: Open confession of Christ is essential for salvation, with heavenly consequences for loyalty to him.

verses.text: 'But whoever denies me before others, I will also deny before my Father who is in heaven.'
verses.comment: Final judgment is connected to our response to Christ in this life. ‘Father in heaven’ emphasizes Jesus’ special relationship to God, a claim to being the Son of God.

verses.text: 'Do not think that I came to bring peace on earth. I did not come to bring peace, but a sword.'
verses.comment: Jesus as the Messiah brings division—even among families—because allegiance to him is above all. The ‘sword’ is a metaphor for sharp division.

verses.text: 'For I have come to set a man against his father, a daughter against her mother, and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.'
verses.comment: Citing Micah 7:6, Jesus shows that following him sometimes results in radical division—echoing Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: 'A person's enemies will be those of his own household.'
verses.comment: Family opposition is expected—even within the household—in the context of faithfulness to Christ.

verses.text: 'Whoever loves father or mother more than me is not worthy of me; and whoever loves son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.'
verses.comment: Ultimate loyalty must be to Christ, which points to his divinity—demanding love and obedience above even family.

verses.text: 'And whoever does not take his cross and follow me is not worthy of me.'
verses.comment: ‘Take up his cross’ means total imitation of Christ, embracing suffering for his sake. This anticipates the reality of discipleship and persecution.

verses.text: 'He who finds his life will lose it, and he who loses his life for my sake will find it.'
verses.comment: Paradoxically, true life is found only in self-surrender to Christ—a central mystery of the Christian faith.

verses.text: 'Whoever receives you receives me, and whoever receives me receives him who sent me.'
verses.comment: Jesus links himself with his apostles; receiving them is equivalent to receiving him, and so, the one who sent him (the Father). This grounds the importance of apostolic authority in the church.

verses.text: 'Whoever receives a prophet because he is a prophet will receive a prophet’s reward; and whoever receives a righteous person because he is a righteous person will receive a righteous person’s reward.'
verses.comment: Affirming the reward for those who show hospitality to Christ’s servants, this stresses the importance of good works and their lasting value.

verses.text: 'And whoever gives even a cup of cold water to one of these little ones because he is my disciple, truly, I tell you, he will never lose his reward.'
verses.comment: Even the smallest act of charity done for Christ’s sake is remembered by God and rewarded, underscoring the reality and importance of deeds of love in the life of faith.
